Integrable hierarchies related to the Kuper-CH spectral problem
Ling Zhang and Dafeng Zuo

text.front:
JOURNAL OF MATHEMATICAL PHYSICS 52, 073503 (2011)
Integrable hierarchies related to the Kuper-CH
spectral problem
Ling Zhang
1,2,a) and Dafeng Zuo
1,3,b)
1 School of Mathematical Science, University of Science and Technology of China,
Hefei 230026, People's Republic of China
2 Department of Mathematics, Chuzhou University, Chuzhou, 239012 Anhui,
People's Republic of China
3 Wu Wen-Tsun Key Laboratory of Mathematics, USTC, Chinese Academy of Sciences
(Received 11 April 2011; accepted 31 May 2011; published online 5 July 2011)
In this paper, from a given Kuper-CH spectral problem, we propose two kinds of
super integrable hierarchies. One is the Kuper-CH hierarchy, the other is the gen-
eralized Kuper-Harry-Dym hierarchy. Moreover, we construct their zero curvature
representations and super-bi-Hamiltonian structures. C
2011 American Institute of
Physics. [doi:10.1063/1.3603817]
text.body:
I. INTRODUCTION
It is well known that the Korteweg-deVries (KdV) equation,
u t = 6uu x − u xxx ,
and the Camassa-Holm (CH in brief) equation,
m t = 4mu x + 2m x u, m = u − u xx ,
are two model equations for water waves, where u(x, t) represents the water's free surface in non-
dimensional variables. But they arise in different regimes (see Refs. 2, 8, and 16): the KdV equation
models long waves of small amplitude, while the CH equation models for waves of moderate
amplitude. On the other hand, both of them admit a bi-Hamiltonian structure, a Lax pair and
are integrable through the inverse scattering/inverse spectral approaches, see Refs. 4, 6, 9, 14, 25,
and 27 and references therein. Moreover, both of them can be regarded as geodesic equations on
certain groups. The KdV equation is the geodesic equation for the right-invariant L
2 -metric on the
Bott-Virasoro group, while the above CH equation is the geodesic equation for the right-invariant
H
1 -metric on the group of diffeomorphisms, see Refs. 5, 7, 17–19, 26, and 28 for details.
In 1984, Kupershmidt
20 proposed a fermionic extension (without supersymmetry) of the KdV
equation (Kuper-KdV in brief) with a Lax pair and a local super-bi-Hamiltonian structure. In
Ref. 28, the Kuper-KdV equation was interpreted as a geodesic flow equation on a superconformal
group G with respect to an L
2 -type metric. Furthermore, it was shown that in Ref. 11 by taking
another L
2 -type metric on G they obtained a one-parameter family of geodesic equations including
a supersymmetric KdV equation in Ref. 24. Besides these, in Ref. 11 by choosing an H
1 -type metric
on G, they proposed a large class of N = 1 fermionic extensions of the CH equation including an
N = 1 supersymmetric CH equation with a single local super-Hamiltonian structure. In Ref. 11,
there are no N = 1 local super-bi-Hamiltonian fermionic extensions of the CH equation (Kuper-
CH in brief), but in an unpublished paper,
10 they obtained this equation. Let us remark that we
independently rediscovered the Kuper-CH equation in Ref. 32.
A natural question is to look for the Lax pair of the Kuper-CH equation. Motivated by the Lax
pair of Kuper-KdV equation, we notice that it is related to the following spectral problem, called

where m = u − u xx is a bosonic function and α = η − 4η xx is a fermionic function and λ is a bosonic
spectral parameter. In this paper, we will study integrable hierarchies related to the Kuper-CH spectral
problem.
This paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II, we study the variational derivative of the Kuper-
CH spectral problem to get a pair of super-Lenard operators K and J . By using K and J , in
Secs. III and IV we propose fermionic extensions of the CH hierarchy and the generalized Harry-
Dym hierarchy. Afterwards, we construct their zero-curvature representations. Furthermore, by using
a super-trace identity we also establish the super-bi-Hamiltonian structure of them. Some concluding
remarks are given in Sec. V.

C. The geometric origin of K and J
Let us remark that the pair of the super-Lenard operators K and J are super-Hamiltonian
operators associated to the Neveu-Schwarz superalgebra, see Refs. 28 and 32 for details.

In bosonic cases, a systematic approach for constructing zero curvature representation has been
well developed by several papers, see Refs. 1,12,21,22,29, and 30 and references therein for details.

text.note:
The Kuper-CH spectral problem
J. Math. Phys. 52, 073503 (2011)
text.body:
C. The super-bi-Hamiltonian structrue
In bosonic cases, in Ref. 31, Tu proposed an approach to Hamiltonian structures of integrable
systems by using of a trace identity. For a variety of isospectral problems that can be unified to
one model x = U 0 , it has been shown that both the related hierarchy of evolution equations and
the Hamiltonian structure can be obtained from the same solution of the equation V x = [U 0 , V ].
A super analogue, i.e., super-trace identity was obtained in Refs. 15 and 23. In this subsection,
we want to use the super-trace identity for the Kuper-CH spectral problem (2.7) to establish the
super-bi-Hamiltonian structure of the Kuper-CH hierarchy (3.3).
Lemma 3.6: (Refs. 15 and 23): For the Kuper-CH spectral problem (2.7), assume that V is a
solution to the stationary zero curvature equation V x = [U, V ] with given homogenous rank. Then
δ

text.body:
IV. THE GENERALIZED KUPER-HARRY-DYM HIERARCHY
By analogy with Sec. III, we will propose another hierarchy related to the Kuper-CH spectral
problem and construct its zero-curvature representation and super-bi-Hamiltonian structure. We only
list these results and omit all proofs.

V. CONCLUDING REMARKS
In this paper, we have introduced the Kuper-CH hierarchy and the generalized Kuper-Harry-
Dym hierarchy from a given Kuper-CH spectral problem and studied their zero curvature repre-
sentations and super-bi-Hamiltonian structures. Let us remark that all resulting hierarchies are not
supersymmetric, only fermionic extensions. A natural question is to extend the above construction
to supersymmetric integrable hierarchies. Another topic is to develop super-analogues of integrable
hierarchies with self-consistent sources. We leave these for future investigations.
text.div:
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
We are grateful to Professors Cheng Yi and Chen Qing for their constant supports and the
anonymous referee for several useful suggestions. This work is partially supported by the Fun-
damental Research Funds for the Central Universities and Natural Science Foundation of China
(NSFC) (10971209, 10871184) and SRF for ROCS, SEM, and the Natural Science Foundation of
Anhui province (KJ2011Z287).
